title: What happens to density if mass increases but the volume remains the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is increasing. Let’s see why: Density, [math]ρ[/math], is equal to mass [math]m[/math], divided by volume, [math]v[/math]. [math]ρ = m / v[/math] By simply observing the above equation, we see that for a constant [math]v[/math], [math]ρ[/math] increases as [math]m[/math] increases. For example, let [math]v = 2[/math] and the initial mass be [math]m = 4[/math]. Then the initial density is [math]ρ = 2[/math]. Now take the final mass to be [math]m = 8[/math], then the final density increase to [math]ρ = 4[/math].

Density = mass/ volume So here is the formula of density and how it is related to mass and volume. Density directly proportional to mass and inversely proportional to volume, if you increase the mass density increases and vice versa, if you increase the volume density decreases and vice versa.
